elements.title: Euphemia Steele Innes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Scottish nurse Euphemia Steele Innes (pictured) was decorated with the Royal Red Cross first class for services with the Territorial Force Nursing Service in World War I?

elements.title: trial of Neumann and Sass (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the trial of Neumann and Sass, held in Lithuania in 1934–1935, is said to be the first mass trial of Nazis in Europe?

elements.title: Andrew Barclay (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Andrew Barclay, a bookbinder in colonial Boston, was commanded by British general Sir Guy Carleton to take Loyalist refugees to Nova Scotia?

elements.title: Book of Common Prayer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the 1962 Book of Common Prayer has been translated into Cree, French, Inuktitut, and Mohawk?

elements.title: Wolfram Menschick (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Johannespassion by Wolfram Menschick, a setting of the Passion according to St John for three soloists and choir, will be performed today at Essen Cathedral?

elements.title: Apple Bank Building (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that New York Times writer David W. Dunlap said calling the Apple Bank Building a neighborhood bank branch "is like calling Grand Central Terminal a commuter train station"?

elements.title: Oksana Shvets (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ukrainian actress Oksana Shvets, who was killed in the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, starred in the 2013 joint Ukrainian–Russian television family saga House with Lilies alongside Russian actors?

elements.title: E. F. Barrett Power Station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that there wasn't enough water in Oceanside to build more than half of the E. F. Barrett Power Station?
